title: Protocol for human placental mesenchymal stem cell therapy in a murine model of intra-abdominal infection of hypervirulent Klebsiella
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
HvKP inocula preparation and inoculation at hour 0
Timing: 21 h
This step details amplification of HvKP for injection and induction of IAI in mice (Wang et al., 2020[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib15]).
Recover the clinical hvKP NVT1001 strain of serotype K1, which was previously isolated from a patient with liver abscess and stored at −80°C, in 20 mL LB broth for 16 h at 37°C.
Dilute the cultured bacteria at 1: 10 with LB broth and keep the bacteria diluent cultured for additional 4 h at 37°C to maintain it in the logarithmic phase of growth.
Adjust the bacteria solution to an optical density of 0.9 at 600 nm (around 4 × 108 colony-forming unit (CFU)/mL based on a previous report of this strain of hvKP (Tsai et al., 2014[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib14])) with a spectrophotometer.
Bacteria were then diluted to a number of 5 × 104 CFU/mL in sterile PBS and maintained on ice until intraperitoneal inoculation. A lethal dose of 5 × 103 CFUs/100 μL which would cause near-absolute lethality within one week was intraperitoneally injected into 6-week old C57BL/6 male mice.
Critical: Since bacteria harbor a very short life cycle of approximately 2 h, it is critical to have an accurate CFU number by adjusting bacteria solution to the suggested optical density and diluting it to the working concentration as soon as possible.
Human placental MSC (PMSC) preparation and injection at hour 2
Timing: 6 days
This step details expansion of human PMSCs for treatment of mice with hvKP-IAI.
Subculture of human PMSCs (Yen et al., 2005[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib17])
Thaw frozen PMSCs: 1 × 106 cells/mL per vial stored in vapor phase liquid nitrogen of approximately −196°C.
Prepare 9 mL pre-warmed MSC culture medium.
Thaw frozen cells rapidly within 1 min in a 37°C water bath.

Add 1 mL of thawed cells into pre-warmed MSC culture medium and collect PMSCs with centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature.
Wash PMSCs with 10 mL pre-warmed PBS, centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature. Repeat this step twice.
Re-suspend the cells in 10 mL pre-warmed MSC culture medium and evenly seed the cells in a 75T flask.
Maintain the cells in a 37°C incubator with humidified atmosphere of 5% CO2 for 1 day.
Replace with 10 mL fresh pre-warmed MSC culture medium.
Culture the cells for another 2 days.
Assess PMSC cultures: density reaching to more than 80% confluence which has at least 2 × 106 PMSCs in 75T flask.
Harvest PMSCs.
Remove spent medium.
Wash cells twice with 10 mL pre-warmed PBS.
Pipette 1 mL 0.25% Trypsin-EDTA onto PMSC monolayer.
Rinse throughout the cells.
Pat the side of 75T flask for 1 min at room temperature.
Examine cells: detaching cells to single cell suspensions.
Pipette 9 mL pre-warmed MSC culture medium to neutralize Trypsin activity.
Collect PMSC suspensions in a 50 mL centrifuge tube with centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature.
Re-suspend PMSCs in 30 mL fresh MSC culture medium for each 75T flask with 10 mL of PMSC suspensions at a dilution of 1:3.
Culture PMSCs for 3 days
Preparation of PMSCs for intraperitoneal injection
Harvest PMSCs.
Remove spent medium.
Wash cells twice with 10 mL pre-warmed PBS.
Pipette 1 mL 0.25% Trypsin-EDTA onto PMSC monolayer.
Rinse throughout the cells.
Pat the side of 75T flask for 1 min at room temperature.
Examine cells: detaching cells to single cell suspensions.
Pipette 9 mL pre-warmed MSC culture medium to neutralize Trypsin activity.

Collect PMSC suspensions in a 50 mL centrifuge tube with centrifugation at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature.
Wash PMSCs with 10 mL pre-warmed PBS, centrifuge at 300 × g for 5 min at room temperature. Repeat this step twice.
Re-suspend the cells in cold PBS and calculate the numbers of live PMSCs by trypan blue dye exclusion method with Neubauer chamber. Finally re-suspend PMSCs in cold PBS at a final concentration of 3 × 106/mL.
Keep the PMSC suspensions on ice until intraperitoneal injection. Then inject 3 × 105/100 μL of PMSCs intraperitoneally into control or infected mice.
Critical: To ensure viability and functional activity of PMSCs, it is critical to collect the cells within 1 min after trypsinization at room temperature. To have consistent results, we suggest that PMSCs are cultured for 3 days after subculture with 1: 3 split to obtain at least 2 × 106 cells for harvest in each experiment.
Isolation of peritoneal cavity cells at hour 18
Timing: 30 min
This step details isolation of mouse peritoneal immune cells without needing to affix the mice to a dissecting board or aspirating with a syringe within the peritoneal cavity 18 h after initial hvKP inoculation (or 16 h after PMSC treatment) (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1])

Figure 1. Isolation of mouse peritoneal immune cells without needing to affix the mice to a dissecting board or aspirating with a syringe within the peritoneal cavity
(A) Euthanize a mouse with CO2 inhalation and spray the mouse with 70% ethanol.
(B) Use scissors and one tissue forceps to transversely cut the skin on the lower abdomen.
(C) Cut the skin longitudinally along the anterior median line.
(D) Remove the ventral skin.
(E) Spray the peritoneum with 70% ethanol.
(F) Wipe the peritoneum with a paper towel.

(G) Use tissue forceps to lift up the peritoneum.
(H) Inject 10 mL of cold PBS into the peritoneal cavity using a 27G needle.
(I) Gently shake the mouse for 1 min to wash the peritoneal cavity.
(J) Tent and distend the abdomen by holding the mouse from the back and tightening skin folds bilaterally, then use a 27G needle to puncture into the peritoneum.
(K) Squeeze out as much PBS-containing peritoneal fluid as possible through punctured site.
(L) Collect the peritoneal washings (approximately 8 mL).
Euthanize a mouse with CO2 inhalation, a commonly used method to sacrifice laboratory animals, with 30% cage volume/min for one min and spray the mouse with 70% ethanol (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]A). Other methods for animal euthanasia in this experiment can be used but should be tested to ascertain to have minimal effects on immune cell activity.
Use scissors and one tissue forceps to transversely cut the skin on the lower abdomen (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]B).
Cut the skin longitudinally along the anterior median line (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]C).
Remove the ventral skin (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]D).
Spray the peritoneum with 70% ethanol (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]E).
Wipe the peritoneum with a paper towel (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]F).
Use tissue forceps to lift up the peritoneum (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]G).
Inject 10 mL of cold PBS into the peritoneal cavity using a 27G needle (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]H). Avoid perforating any organs.
Hold both sides of removed skin to gently shake the mouse for 1 min to allow injected PBS to circulate within the peritoneal cavity (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]I).
Tent and distend the abdomen by holding the mice from the back and tightening skin folds bilaterally, then use a 27G needle to puncture into the peritoneum (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]J). Avoid perforating any organs.
Squeeze out as much PBS-containing peritoneal fluid as possible through punctured site into a 10-cm dish (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]K).

Collect the peritoneal washings (Figure 1[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig1]L) and keep on ice until processing.
Critical: It is critical to use only sterile equipment and sterile materials, and harvest peritoneal washings without touching the removed skin to prevent contamination with normal skin flora interfering in the following hvKP CFU counting assay.
Staining of peritoneal cavity cells for flow cytometric analyses
Timing: 2 h
This step details staining of cells collected from peritoneal washings for flow cytometric analysis of PMN, T and NK cells using V-bottom 9-well microplate (Bingham et al., 2015[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib2]; Lehmann et al., 2017[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib4]).
Cell preparation
Calculate live cells by trypan blue dye exclusion method with Neubauer chamber: approximately 8 × 106 peritoneal cavity cells can be harvested from each control animal while more than 5 × 107 cells can be collected from each hvKP-infected animal.
Transfer 2 × 105 peritoneal cavity cells per well into V-bottom 96-well microplate.
Pellet cells by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink (Cells will be kept in the bottom of each well in the V-plate).
Re-suspend cells with 200 μL cold PBS.
Pellet cells by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink.
Surface staining
Re-suspend cells with 200 μL staining buffer at room temperature for 10 min to prevent non-specific binding.
Pellet cells by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink.
Re-suspend cells with 50 μL staining buffer with antibody mix. Single fluorescent marker of each fluorophore is also prepared for compensation controls using pooled samples from control and infected mice.
Incubate at 4°C for 30 min in the dark.

Pellet cells by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink.
Wash cells twice with 200 μL cold PBS.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink.
Fixation of antibody
Re-suspend cells with 100 μL fixation buffer for 10 min.
Pellet cells by centrifuging at 300 × g for 5 min at 4°C.
Remove supernatant by flicking liquid within the well plate into the sink.
Re-suspend cells with 200 μL PBS.
Keep samples in the dark at 4°C until data collection.
Critical: It is critical to perform red blood cell lysis before step 19a if inadvertent contamination occurs during the process of collecting peritoneal lavage. (see Troubleshooting 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#troubleshooting])
Collection of flow cytometric data
Timing: 1.5 h
The step details flow cytometric data acquisition using BD FACSVerse flow cytometer according to published protocols (Maecker and Trotter, 2006[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib6]).
Condition setting at low (12 μL/min) flow rate
Unstained sample was applied to set appropriate PMT voltages to identify immune cells in forward versus side scatter (FSC versus SSC) gating first, and then by adjusting the logarithmic scale of each fluorescence channel to baseline levels.
Single stained samples of each fluorophore were applied to set appropriate compensation condition to correct the signals of inherent fluorescence spillover.
Data collection and analysis
Deliver the plate or tube racks with 2 × 105 peritoneal cavity cells/200 μL PBS/sample to the BD FACSVerse system for acquisition at high (120 μL/min) flow rate.
Perform the analyses with gating for CD45 first and then CD3, NK1.1, or Ly6G.

Critical: It is critical to adjust PMT voltage gains first using an unstained sample, and then correct for fluorescence spillover using compensation controls since the PMT voltage is correlated with the degree of compensation. For flow cytometric analyses, it is possible to use older equipment such as FACSCalibur.
Measurement of bacterial load
Timing: 18 h
This step details bacterial plating of peritoneal lavage fluid on LB agar plates for quantification of bacterial CFUs (Sutherland et al., 2008[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib11]).
Make 1:10 serial dilutions of each sample (50 μL into 450 μL cold PBS).
Spread 100 μL of each dilution onto LB agar plates.
Incubate plates at 37°C for 16 h.
Count the number of CFU for all dilutions of each sample.
Critical: It is critical to keep all samples on ice to minimize hvKP growth until plating on LB agar plates.
